importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the start of Nicolas Sarkozy's five-year prison sentence, a significant political event as he becomes the first former EU head of state to be jailed.
The day of his sentencing and imprisonment represents a turning point in French political history, signaling accountability for former leaders.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-year jail term begins on October 21, 2025, and will conclude in October 2026, marking the duration of Sarkozy's imprisonment.
The court has two months to review the release appeal, which would allow for potential early release before the full term ends.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, is serving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy related to illegal campaign financing from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of state in the European Union to be imprisoned, marking a significant moment in European political accountability.
The sentence was upheld despite his denial of wrongdoing and despite his legal team filing an appeal for release.
Sarkozy is to be held in solitary confinement in a nine-square-metre cell, with limited contact and one daily walk, due to security measures.
He will receive visits three times a week and is expected to be incarcerated until at least 2026, though early release is possible through the appeal process.
Public outrage and support from citizens and family members reflect deep societal division over the case.
The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity,' justifying the mandatory jail term even with an appeal.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has begun a five-year prison term at La Sante prison in Paris after being convicted of criminal conspiracy for accepting illegal campaign funds from Muammar Gaddafi. He is the first former head of state in the European Union to be imprisoned, marking a pivotal moment in European political accountability. The court, led by judge Nathalie Gavarino, deemed the offenses of 'exceptional gravity,' resulting in a mandatory jail term despite Sarkozy's denial and legal appeal for release. He will be held in solitary confinement with limited interaction, and while the full term is set for 2026, an appeal could lead to early release. Public reaction has been mixed, with supporters expressing sorrow and others criticizing the verdict as unjust.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
